name: 安い
meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cheap? It's also cheap. Time to go to a 100円 shop and get some 安い goods, ammiright?
reading_mnemonic:
Would you like this item for cheap?
Uh, yes (やす) please!

name: 一
meaning_mnemonic: The meaning is same as kanji's.
reading_mnemonic: The reason is same as kanji's

name: 一日
meaning_mnemonic: This word has two different meanings. One day and first day. No matter how you look at this word, those meanings make a lot of sense.
reading_mnemonic: Here you just have to combine the onyomi reading of both kanji's.

name: いつ
meaning_mnemonic: WHEN I will see a TSUnami? (I TSU)
reading_mnemonic: The reading is more than obvious.

name: 二
meaning_mnemonic: The meaning is same as the kanji.
reading_mnemonic: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it usually uses the kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception to this. Numbers use the on'yomi reading, which you've already learned by learning the kanji's reading! How nice!

name: 三
meaning_mnemonic: The meaning is same as the kanji.
reading_mnemonic: When a vocab is alone like this with no okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) it usually uses its kun'yomi reading. Numbers are an exception, though, and use the on'yomi reading. You learned the on'yomi reading when you learned this kanji, so you already know that the reading for this vocab is さん.

name: 四
meaning_mnemonic: The meaning is same as the kanji.
reading_mnemonic: How many times you need to yawn (よん) to be satisfied? Right, 4 times! You can also use the onyomi reading (し)

name: 五
meaning_mnemonic: This vocab is made from a single kanji, which means it shares the same meaning as the parent kanji: Five.
reading_mnemonic: Since numbers are an exception, this word is read using the on'yomi reading even though it's made from a single kanji all alone. Luckily for you, you learned the reading for this word when you learned the parent kanji.

name: 大きい
meaning_mnemonic: The meaning is preety simple. Just keep in mind that this is bigger than plain big :)
reading_mnemonic: What do you do when you see something really, really big? You say おお because you can't believe your eyes.

name: 大人
meaning_mnemonic: An ADULT is in other words a BIG PERSON.
reading_mnemonic: When you are an ANDULT what do you need the most? Oh, toner (おとな) ! You need your skin to look good and stop agging.

name: 人
meaning_mnemonic: Humans take hit after hit, Oh!(ひと). Life can be often harsh, esspecialy when you can get to learn a kanji!
reading_mnemonic: The kanji and the radical have the same meaning.

name: 一人
meaning_mnemonic: When there's one person, what are they? Well, they're either just going to be simply one person or alone
reading_mnemonic: We have to learn the kunyomi for 一 which is ひと, you can associate it again with a "Hit, oh!" not again.. The kunyomi for people is り. People for sure are ri(り)diculous sometimes!

name: 一つ
meaning_mnemonic: You have ONE thing, つ often stands for object counter.
reading_mnemonic: We have to learn the kunyomi for 一 which is ひと, you can associate it again with a "Hit, oh!" not again.. !

name: 月
meaning_mnemonic: The meaning correspond to it's kanji!
reading_mnemonic: To conquer the moon you need at least two keys (つき) to discover the hidden treasure.

name: 一月
meaning_mnemonic: You have ONE MONTH
reading_mnemonic: The kunyomi for 一 which you may have learnt is ひと, you can associate it again with a "Hit, oh!" not again.. ! The reading for moon you've already learnt.

name: この
meaning_mnemonic: THIS in japanese have different readings: この, これ .. It's not that hard, NO?
reading_mnemonic: Luckily you don't need a reading mnemonic! ^^.

name: これ
meaning_mnemonic: THIS in japanese have different meanings: この, これ, .. It seems that THIS REpeats itself :)
reading_mnemonic: Luckily you don't need a reading mnemonic! ^^.

name: ごろ
meaning_mnemonic: What do you do when you want to know an APPROXIMATELY value? You just GO on the ROad and ask people. For example "what time it is?"
reading_mnemonic: Luckily you don't need a reading mnemonic! ^^.

name: さあ
meaning_mnemonic: This is more likely a expression that you use when you take a short break to think about. You cand also think about it as: "let's see", or "uummmm...".
reading_mnemonic: さあ... Luckily you don't need a reading mnemonic! ^^.

name: 〜さん
meaning_mnemonic: I guess you've already heard about attaching SAN at the end of every adult name. Be carreful, if you don't do it people could take is as a sign of disrespect. So keep in mind: SAN SAN SAN, Foxy-SAN!
reading_mnemonic: Luckily you don't need a reading mnemonic! ^^.

name: 学生
meaning_mnemonic: Who has a study life? Only one person that I know of, and that's a student.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

name: 友達
meaning_mnemonic: A friend that you attain is your friend. This is the most common way to say "friend," so learn it if you want to make any!
reading_mnemonic: Think of it this way. You have your friend Tom (とも) Cruise. You like him, and he likes you. You're close enough friends that you can touch (だち) each other too. Like, on the shoulder or on the hand or whatever, without it being awkward. So, you like to Tom touch (ともだち) when you can, because he has nice skin.

name: 元気
meaning_mnemonic: What is the origin of your energy? It is your spirit and health (though this vocab word also means energy as well).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

name: うん
meaning_mnemonic: That should be very easy if you have watched anime.
reading_mnemonic: You don't need a mnemonic here.

name: ううん
meaning_mnemonic: That should be very easy if you have watched anime.
reading_mnemonic: You don't need a mnemonic here.

name: でも
meaning_mnemonic: BUT the DEMO is very important. Don't you think?
reading_mnemonic: You don't need a mnemonic here.

name: 明日
meaning_mnemonic: A bright day isn't today (because today was terrible), it's tomorrow, because you can always look to tomorrow to be a better, brighter day.
reading_mnemonic: The reading makes no sense at all. You have to learn it straight up, and can't rely on the kanji it's made from. Why is tomorrow going to be such a bright and awesome day? Because you're making ash tacos for dinner, and that's your favorite. Imagine imagining tomorrow, full of ash tacos and deliciousness. Maybe you could use some of those Dorito taco shells?

name: 今日
meaning_mnemonic: The now day is what day? Oh, it's today.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is a complete exception, though the word itself is incredibly common and useful. When you think of "today" think about what you have to do today for work.

name: 私
meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: If you're lucky, you already know this (very) common word's reading. It's the word for "I," probably one of the first things you'd learn in Japanese. The reading for this is わたし. If you don't know that already, just think: "What, a し?" referring to the reading of the kanji, which is し.

name: 誰
meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

name: 試験
meaning_mnemonic: If you attempt a test, you're taking an examination. There are a lot of these in Japan, so make sure you know this word if you want to fit in with all the whining and whinging that students do, especially come the final year of high school.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
